document.text: Womans Club Lists Opening Fall Meeting o The first meeting of the Appo mattox Womans Club for the 1955- 1956 season will be held Monday, September 12 at 300 p. m. in the Appomattox High School Cafeteria. Hostesses for the meeting will be Mrs. G. F. Abbitt, Jr., Mrs. H. C. Pulliam, Mrs. J. D. McDeamon and Mrs. H. Y. Spencer. The program for the meeting is designed to acquaint both new mem bers and old with the scope of Womans Club work. The chairmen of the departments will discuss the work of their departments. These include Mrs. F. F. Carr, Chairmen of the American Home Department Mrs. H. A. Gurney, Chairman of Educa tion and International Affairs Mrs. J. R. Lawson, Chairman of Public Affairs and Legislation Mrs. Mil dred Alvis, Chairman of the Welfare Department and Mrs. Roger Nor fleet, Chairman of Fine Arts.  Mrs. Joel W. Flood, Vice-president of the Alice Kyle District of the Vir ginia Federation of Womans Clubs, will discuss the work of Womans Clubs on a district and state level and Mrs. Charles F. P. Crawley will talk about the General Federation of Womans Clubs, which has a total membership of eleven million women. A coffee hour at 300 oclock will precede the business meeting which starts at 330.

Bishop, public relations official of Radio WRVA, Richmond, at a din ner meeting of the Womans. Club of Appomattox Monday night. The dinner meeting was attended by 100 members and guests at the Elemen tary school cafeteria. Mrs. C. F. P. Crawley, president, presided. State Senator Chas. T. Moses introduced the speaker. Charles . Jenkins, Jr. entertaretained with dinner music at the piano. The program was present ed by the Legislation Department of the club, of which Mrs. J. R. Law son is chairman.

document.text: Without our volunteers we could not begin the annual Cancer Cru sade campaign, said Mrs. Chas. F. P. Crawley, chairman, today. The chairman, a volunteer her. self, said, When I talk about vol unteers, I am referring to doctors, nurses, teachers, bankers, druggists, Store - keepers, housewives, high school girls and boys, Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts.. almost anyone you can think of .. because they all have a stake in the great fight. She added that the Appomattox unit is aiming to raise 900 this year. This means person to person contact. It is only through talking with a person that the complex prob lem of cancer can be presented with the utmost force. And when we talk with people during April, which is Cancer Con trol Month by act of Congress, we are not merely asking for money as important as that is. We are tell ing them of our educational pro gram, of how they can watch for the danger signals, or how they can save their own lives, perhaps, and those of their loved ones by alertness and prompt action, I am happy to report that in the course of our campaign in years gone by, our doctors reported more people coming to them for check ups, more people showing up with early cancers that were in the cur able stage, than at any other time of the year, she said. With our enlarged and enthusiastic group of volunteer workers, we should make a better record than ever this year. The money raised in Appomattox will be used for the year - around program of education, service and research. This means preparation of educational material for distribu tion through every possible media, the provision of dressings and oth er sickroom comforts to cancer patients being treated at home, the contribution to tnc re search program which will ultimate ly find the answer to cancer. Persons or groups interested in aiding the Cancer Societys drive may contact Mrs. Crawley by call ing either 3252 or 2401.

It was announced that the Appo mattox Garden Club has been in vited to enter an arrangement in the flower show,  Tobaccoland in Bloom to be presented by the Hali fax County Council of Garden Clubs Oct. 15 and 16 in the Vaughan Armory in South Boston. The club has accepted this invitation, and Mrs. R. C . Hubbard, Mrs. K . C. Gre gory and Mrs. F . F . Carr will make the arrangement. Announcement has been made of the flower show to be held at the armory in Bedford on Oct. 7, and of the Lynchburg Flow er Show presented by the Edgewood Garden Club and Garden Path Gar den Club at Memorial ,Christian Church Oct. 1 from 3 to 9 P. M. The club decided to plant a dog wood tree at the Surrender Grounds in memory of Mrs. Bessie V . Cald well and mark it as such. This dog wood planting along the Hal Flood Highway has been chosen as a mem orial project of the club. Mrs. L. Crawley was appointed as chairman of a resolution committee in mem ory of Mrs. Caldwell, a past presi dent of the club and an active mem ber for many years. This years yearbook is also dedicated to her memory. Three Peace Roses will be award ed at the close of the club year. One will be for the exhibitor who wins the most points in horticulture by bringing horticulture specimens to and receiving awards at monthly meetings one to the amateur ar ranger who wins the most points by receiving ribbons at monthly meet ings, and a third to the novice ar ranger one who has not won a blue ribbon in a flower show or three rib bons at monthly meetings who re ceives the most points at monthly meetings. document.text: With a total of nearly 800 persons employed in the six garm ent factories serving Appomattox County, it may well be said that Appomattox County is doing its part in keeping the nation clothed. The garment industry had its beginning in Appomattox Coun ty in the late 1930s. The factory began operation in the A. T. Inge Store Building on Main S treet. There w ere twenty-eight machines, four teen on each side of the second-floor location, according to Mrs. A. T. Inge, who at the time, with her husband, the late Allison Inge was operating Inges Store on the first floor ol the building. Financed by businessmen in Appomattox, the first garment company had the late Lindsey Crawley as President and W illie M itchell as  plant manager. document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox.  And death itself, to him, was but The wider opening of the door Tha had been opening, more and more, Through all his life, and nevei as stiut. . . .

document.text: Welcome Home from the Open Road, was the theme of the 5th year Reunion of the 1 46 Gradua ting Class of the Appomattox High School, held on Saturday evening, June 2, in the high school cafeteria A reunion dinner featured the oc casioin. Gypsy music and decorations were carried out for the class theme, The Open Road. The class colors of red and white dominated the room with a background of pines with tent and campfire. Mrs. Mary Spiggre Hudson, vice president of the class, served as toastmistress in the absence of the president, Garland H. Reynolds, who is now serving in the Navy. The toastmistress acknowledged a vacant chair at the head of the table stating, This is in remem brance of our beloved chieftan principal L. Crawley, who has pass ed on higher camping ground. Guests for the evening other than class members included J. A. Burke, superintendent of schools Mrs. J, A. Burke, and Miss Harriett Holley and Mrs. W. M. Morris, class spon sors. Topics of interest to the class members were reviewed as follows Class history, Nellwyn OBrien Class prophecy, Nell Williamson Cabaniss Class mirror, Ann Housman, sec retary of class Last will and testament, Alice Jennings Layne, class treasurer. To the mothers of the tribe the toastmistress presented earrings to bind them and the class closer to gether. The roll was called by the sponsors and each member present answered, giving a brief review if his or her experience on the open road during the past five years. Class members present included

document.text: weeks now Slates of delegates to district and state conventions were elected at a Democratic mass meeting last Fri day night at the court house. The meeting adopted two resolutions one endorsing Watkins M. Abbitt for renomination and re-election to Congress from the Fourth District, introduced by Calvin Robinson and one endorsing the record of United States Senator Harry F. Byrd, in troduced by C. W. Smith. Congressman W. M. Abbitt was present and addressed the meeting. Charles F. P. Crawley served as the presiding officer of the meeting and C. W. Smith served as secretary. The following delegates, instruct ed to vote as a unit, were named to the Fourth District Convention in Petersburg, May 24 J. A. Bingham, George Abbitt, Jr. G. T. Moses, Sr. G. B. Buchanan, J. H. document.text: Wednesday, October 16, has been designated as Regis.ra.ion Day for all men 21 to 35, inclusive, under the draft law enacted by Congress and signed by the President. The regular election precincts will be us ed as registration places, with the election officials acting as officials.  Charles Crawley, secretary of the Appomattox county electoral board, will attend a meeting next week in Richmond, when details of the regis tration procedure will be explained to the election officials.

document.text: We are glad to see Mr. Crawley back at school after a short illness. . Who can tell us to whom Verta Martin has given her heart lately? Whoever it is, he has sent Verta, smiling through the air. Willie, did you have special bus iness in Gladstone over the week end, or did you just go over to see the beautiful scenery? It is rather strange that where we live affects our social ife. For example, Elizabeth lives a long way from the highway and Henry cant get there so easily, but he takes advantage of Mary Frances living near the highway. Arent you glad, Mary, that you can be easily reached? Senator Moses spoke to one of the Civics classes Tuesday on th e government of Virginia. It was very! interesting. We are all very grateful to Mr. Lusardi for making some volley i ball courts. It is wonderful to have i someone at school who takes an  interest in sports for the pupils. The Canteen will be held on Thursday night. lit is t obe spon sored by the Citizens Party. Weve missed Mrs. Harwood this week, who has been home on ac count of sickness. Some oi oui students are still at home with the flu, but many have returned,and our attendance is better than last week. Mrs. Cheatham went to Rich mond last week to an art exhibit at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts. Among the paintings was one by her daughter, Mary Frances, who is now studying at Mary Wash ington College. We hope you all will have a tHappy Easter and also that the Easter Bunny will go to you. Well see you back at school Tuesday. So - long!

document.text: was never any intimation on my part, or the part of any one else, to Mr- Crawley, or anyone, that I would ask that his salary be increased, until after the fight was over, and no inducement of any kind was offered Mr. Craw ley by anyone to withdraw as an applicant for Superintendent of Schools of Appomattox County. I understand Mr. Featherston resigned as Superintendent of Schools to accept a more lucra tive position in Richmond, and not because of any agreement with or promise to the State Board of Education or yourself to resign. I am writing to ask you to write a letter, addressed to me, which I will with your permission, publish stating whether any agreement was made between the State Board of Education and Mr. Feather ston, or with you or anyone else, that he should resign at the ex piration of one year, and also, if appointment was not for a full four year term without any reservations of any kind, Sincerely yours, J. W. Flood.

document.text: Walter G. Schnee, Director of the Studio of Interior Decorating and Homefurnishings Coordinator f or Miller A Rroads, Richmond, will speak before the Womans Club of Appomattox on Monday, February 1, at 3 P. M., at Mauds Hot Shop. The program is being presented by the American Home Department of the club. Mrs. Charles F. P. Crawley, program chairman, will present Mr. Schnee. The hostesses for the afternoon are Mrs. Otis Dewberry, Mrs. Lau rence Gilliam, Mrs. Julian Hesson. Mrs. John S. Grinels, Mrs. Charles R. Thomas and Mrs. A. R. Harwood, Jr. Mr. Schnee is a graduate of Princeton University and the Par sons School of Design in New York. He has practiced in the field of in terior decoration for the past twelve years and came to Richmond from Strawbridge and Clothier in Phila delphia. Prior to that time, he was affiliated with Lord  Taylor of New York. As director of the Studio of In terior Decoration, Mr. Schnee is in charge of correlating the efforts of the seven professional interior deco- ators who are associated with it. Their work not only includes private homes throughout several states but also commercial institutional build ings of many different types. As Homefurnishings Coordinator for the store, he is in charge of the presentation to the public of the merchandise of the many different departments within the homefurnish ings field which are represented in the store. He is directly responsible for the many exhibits and education al events which are staged on behalf of this division during the course of each year.

document.text: W edding Saturday X  Invitations have been issued by Dr. and Mrs. L. L. Morgan of Gladys to the marriage of their daughter, Mary Burroughs to Nor- vin Green Maloney of Baltimore. The wedding will take place at Kedrin Baptist church at Gladys on Satur day August 10 at 430 in the after noon. Dr. J . P. McCabe of Mar tinsville, assisted by the Rev J Hilton Garner, pastor of the church will officiate. Miss Katherine Price Morgan, sis ter of the bride .will be maid of honor. Bridesmaids will include Miss Vio let Ramsey, of Appomattox Misses Janet Phillips and Elizabeth Clay of Gladys and Miss Virginia McDonald of Norfolk. Junior bridesmaid will be Jane Morgan, sister of the bride. Groomsmen will include Charles P. Crawley of Appomattox and Dr. Morgan, of Franklin, brother of the bride. Cards to a reception immediately! after the ceremony at the home of the brides parents, have been sent to relatives, out of town guests and a few close friends of the couple.

Long, Bridgewater, io Agnes H atton, Tanners Creek.  8  W alter Sm ith, H ickory,  8  John Smith, National Soldiers Home, Eliza beth City County,  8  John Arrnel. Armcl, io Levin Griffin, Townsend,  8  AvecyB. Howell. Roan.-ike,  8  Israel Butt, Berkley,  6 . Dick C arter shot and fatally wounded Clarence Hodges, aged 18 years, in H odges home, in Roanoke. It seems that Carter, who hails from W inston, N. C., went to Roanoke with a companion named Shelton. They were going to W est Virginia, but, it is alleged, C arter drank heavily and went ino the room s over a saloon occupied by. Fannie H odges and her son. H e claimed to be a Secret Service agent of the Governm ent, it is said, and un dertook to dislodge the tenants. W il liam M artin grappled with hint in his attempt to shoot young Hodges, but . failed in his effort. The bullet entered the left side of tire neck and evidently lodged about the spinal cord. H is en tire body was paralyzed and his con dition is extrem ely serious, fa rte r at tempted to escape, but was captured and lodged in jail. A trial in Stafford County Court in volving the ownership of a cow afford ed much amuiement to a large crowd of spectators. Joe Baker had been a tenant on the Green Bank farm of M ajor W. S. Ernbrey for 16 years, and was displaced. In turning over the farm property Baker claimed a certain cow as thc property of his wife. M ajor Embrcy was confident thc cow belong ed to him. The case first came up in a m agistrates court, and was removed to thc County C ourt of Stafford, where four lawyers took part in the proceed ings before Judge Chichester. .The case went against Baker, and wasap pealed, and will b e . carried to the cir cuit Court. Mrs. Baker, who claims the cow, though only 43 years old, is thc m other of 17 children. 1.4 of whom arc living and 5 are married. In the Circuit Court at W inchester. S. H. Braithvvaite was given 1200 damages against Charles K. M cllwee for alienation of his wifes affections. Mr. Baithwaite asked for 5000 dam  ages, claiming that M cllwee had not only alienated his wifes affections, but had also caused her to desert him and his five children. All the parties con cerned are prom inent residents of the county. Some sensational evidence was introduced during the trial. G eorge Christian, colored, was elec trocuted at N ew port News by coming in contact with a live wire. H e caught hold of the wire leading to a 16 -candle- power light at a point where the insu lation was worn off. It is thought the feed wire m ust have been crossed witlj a street wire, as death was instantane ous and there was current enough to burn off three fingers. The barn of J. A. Storm , near Lew- insville, Fairfax county, was burned and 14 horses and four cows were burned or lost in the fire. J t is esti mated that the loss will be over  4000 . Panhandle coal operators refuse to accept the scale adopted at thc subdis trict conference and state that they will oppose it to the last. Business men of Crewe have formed a trade organization, with these officers President, Thomas B. O liver first vice- president, C. E. W ilson secretary, B. N. W aterhouse treasurer, Capt. E. F. Loc kett. The Virginia Anthracite Coal Com pany is building a railroad to open up the large area of coal lands iii Mont gomery county. The line will later be extended so as to run from Christian- burg to Blacksburg. George Tinsley, one of five negroes charged with robbing German sailors of the steamship Albano, was given eight years in the penitentiary ait Newport News. The evidence showed that i ins- ley was in the crowd that beat the sail ors. The fact that several German coins lost by one of the sailors were found in his pockets convicted him. Thc Jamestown Exposition advocates in thc House have thc whip-hand, and succeeded in defeating the bill to appro priate an additional  100,000 for the im provement and enlargement of the Capi tol. They also succeeded in having April 2 set as a date for again taking up the Jamestown appropriation. 1 he Mann Prohibition bill was prac tically killed in the Senate Finance Com mittee after being so amended as not to apply to towns of over 1,000 or to sum mer resorts. A business mens league has been formed at Buena Vista with R. W. VVin- borne as president. Anoth i-annery is under construction at the lower end of Arnolds Valley, Rockbridge county, owned by R. McC. Paxton  Bro. and T. Rapp. The contracts have been let for build- ing-at Cape Henry a pavillion which will accommodate 15.000 people and cost  30 , 000 , and also for bathhouses near by. The buildings will he finished in about 60 days. W ork will begin this wreek. Fish -are beginning to run well in the Potomac and Rapnahannock rivers and their tributaries. H erring arc now sell ing for i.Co per hundred, shad 40 cents to 80 cents a pair, perch 15 cents to 50 cents a bunch and rockfish 30 cents to 60 cents a hunch. Sheriff Curtis, of Hamoton. has re ceived information that Emmett Lends, colored, who is wanted in Hampton on the charge of killing George Davidson, is in Cincinnati. Samuel Carey, colored, said to be the oldest man in Virginia, died at his home on M ulberry Island, in W arwick county. Carey leaves several sons, all of whqm have reached an advanced age. H e claimed to be 117 years old. At W illiam sburg the jury acquitted Nancy Thornton, the negro conjur er, who was charged with the m urder of her husband. The m arriage of Miss K atherine Crawley to Mr. Elisha W oodfin M ad ison is announced to take place at Centenary Church, Stoddcrt, on April 1 st.

City officials of Portsmouth, incens ed at the dekiy of the street car com pany in replacing the alleged rotten ties on Court street before the laying ot asphalt pavement there is begun, went out with axes and chopped the ties they found too rotten to last. The officials do not wish to have the asphalt taken up within a year or two to replace rot ten ties, even though the railway com pany is obligated to repair the pave ment at its own expense. Many ties t were chopped, so they must now be re placed. . . The Evangelical and Prohibition As sociation will hold its twenty-sixth an nual assembly near Purcellville August 4, continuing one week. An auditorium has just been, completed 80 by 160 feet, with a seating capacity of 3000. Arming the speakers to be present are Rev. George R. Stewart, of Tennessee Silas C. Swallow, of Pennsylvania, and L. A. Coulter, of Virginia Mrs. E. N. Bur gess, of New York, and Rev. George Waverly Briggs, of Kentucky. Mr. D. J. Hoge. of Lincoln, is chairman, and Mr. C. C. Gaver, of Hillsboro, secre- tary. Benjamin Brown, colored, was run over and killed near the Southern Rail road depot in Alexandria. He was supposed to have been trying to steal a ride to Lynchburg. John M. Oakey, of Roanoke, has been appointed a member of the State Embalming Bard- T. J. Anderson, a carpenter, 53 years of age, of Norfolk, fell from the scaf folding in a skylight on which he was at work in a new building and was kilb ed. He fell through the lightshaft to the floor, 45 feet below and was crush ed. Anderson was standing on a car penters horse and got so near the end that the horse tipped, and he fell between the planks to his death. The election held in Lynchburg to de cide whether the Council should appro priate 700,000 for bringing water from the mountains of Amherst county by gravity resulted in 1,244 for the gravity system and 178 against it. This means that Lynchburg will erect a 6o-foot dam on Pedlar river, 25 miles distant, and construct a reservoir to hold 1,000,000,- 000 gallons of water. The system will bring water through a 36-inch pipe across the Tobacco Row Mountains, over James river, six miles above the city, and thence through Bedford to the city reservoir, which will be 250 feet be low the Pedlar intake. The pipe will probably be constructed of wooden staves. Three pipe-line routes have been surveyed, the last one, which will prob-  ably be selected, having been under the direction of James H. Fuerte, of New Lynchburg. . York, and City Engineer Shaner, ot I James F. Ford, who disappeared in February front Gloucester county, has returned to his home. A few hours after I his marriage Mr. Fofd left his bride, 1 saying he would return in a short time, I and went aboard his oyster boat. He I was traced to Newport News, after which the clue was lost. The latter part I of February a body found at Norfolk I was identified as that of Ford and was buried by his relatives, who mourned I him as dead. Mr. Ford says he has been in New Jersey. . . . . . . I The General officers of the Virginia and Southwestern Railway were moved I into the new Burson Building, at Bris tol. The offices of the Virginia Iron, Coal and Coke Company, with a force of about 50 men, will be moved there from Radford, within the next few days. Alexandrias municipal expenses foi the closing fiscal year were 163,627.99 the receipts were exactly the same. I ms is nearly double the amount expended by Alexandria in any other year since i860. The Confederate Memorial Literary Society has a project that asks for the four streets that meet at the Lee Monu ment, Richmond, be named Westmore land, Arlington, Lexington and Rich mond. , .  . . Janies If. Cox, son of R. M. Cox, of Eltiston, was run over and mangled by a freight train near Richlands. Alexander Hamner, a business man of Graham, fell from a passenger train at Bluestone Junction and was instantly killed. He was standing on the platform and lost his balance. Frank Perry, colored, assaulted bam- uel Sport, colored, in the city jail at Newport News. He used a razor ssa slashed Sport, inflicting several wounds. Sport had just been admitted to the jail. Tlie cutting is said to have resulted from a fight over a woman. Farmers in the Woodstock section are harvest! but have been retarded by continued showers. The grain is plump and of fine quality. Police Sergeant Graves had a des perate fight with a crazy negro confin ed in the Roanoke city jail. The negro created great excitement and- secured the padlock to his cell. Sergeant Graves attempted to get it from him, when the negro sprang upon him, and a desper ate struggle ensued. The negro praying while the struggle was on, and it was not until two other policemen I arrived that he was overpowered. Mrs. Lula Brame, a widow, and I Leighton Kershaw, of Lynchburg, I eloped to Pelham, N. C., and were I married there Saturday night. Ker- I shaw is only 19 years old and his pa- I rents opposed the marriage on account I of his youth.  A young lady is now manager of the Williamsburg telephone system. ! Work is still going on the copper I shaft on Hook mountain, Page county, I which is now 175 feet deep. Little rain has fallen in the Abing I don section for 51 days and crops and I cattle are suffering. Secretary Root has extended until I October 1 the time in which Sculptor I E. V. Valentine is to finish the model 1 of the statue of Gen. Hugh Mercer, I which the Government will place in I Fredericksburg. The work was to have I been done by June 1. Hon A. C. Braxton, of Staunton, in a letter to Mr. C. V. Meredith, of Kicn-  mond, made, public, says he is not now and does ndt anticipate, situated as nc is, that he K ill be a candidate in 1905 for United fetates Senator or any other office. Hefexpresses his appreciation of offers I f support, which he says i have com  from all sections of t . State. M

document.text: Victory iserviqes were i conduct ed at the Appomattox High School assembly Tuesday, when both the grade and high school pupils and their teachers observed the end of the war in Europe. Rev. Mr. Ross spoke of the responsibilities of the surrender. Principal L. Crawley called attention to the fact that the surrender was made in a lit tle red school house somewhere in France. He pointed out that it was significant that the surrender was signed at a school house, for he believed that it was in a little school house in Germany or oth ers like it, that the rudiments of war first started!. It further re veals, Mr. Crawley declared, that  he school houses in America hold the key to future peace or future war. He said the discerning ey can already see practices and teachings right here in America .hat most assuredly count for peace, and we must watch for for ces entering our schools that will turn peace into war. Keep an eye on this litle red school houie, he said. It is a lever that works both ways. B1 ue Mold Cuts Leal Plants
